<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0035" view="all">Flexible zwitterion ligands 1,1′,1″‑(2,4,6‑trimethylbenzene‑1,3,5‑triyl)‑tris(methylene)tris ‑(4‑carboxypyridinium)tribromide (L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>) and 1,2,4,5‑tetrakis‑(4‑carboxylatopyridinium‑1‑methylene)benzene (L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) were used for construction of three novel luminescent d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>-based coordination polymers, namely {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BDC)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·2Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·2EtOH·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possessed one-dimensional <ce:italic>zig</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>zag</ce:italic> linear chain, while the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> possessed three–dimensional supramolecular polymers by hydrogen bonding interaction. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be applied as a potential multi-functional luminescent sensing material for selective and recyclable sensing of nitrobenzene (NB), Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion through fluorescence quenching based detection method. The structures were structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA).</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Flexible zwitterion ligands 1,1',1"-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl)-tris(methylene)tris -(4-carboxypyridinium)tribromide (L1) and 1,2,4,5-tetrakis-(4-carboxylatopyridinium-1-methylene)benzene (L2) were used for construction of three novel luminescent d10-based coordination polymers, namely {[Cd2L1 2(BDC)(H2O)6]⋅2Br-⋅2EtOH⋅3H2O}n (1), [Zn(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (2) and [Cd(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (3). The structure of 1 possessed one-dimensional zig-zag linear chain, while the structure of 2 and 3 possessed three-dimensional supramolecular polymers by hydrogen bonding interaction. Complex 1 can be applied as a potential multi-functional luminescent sensing material for selective and recyclable sensing of nitrobenzene (NB), Fe3+ ion and HSO4 - anion through fluorescence quenching based detection method. The structures were structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, and thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA).

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Three novel luminescent d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>-based Coordination Polymers (CPs) have been synthesized and structurally characterized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be sensing recyclable of NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was conducted from multi-arm zwitterion ligand.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Nowadays, with the development of modern industry, environmental pollution has become a worldwide problem. Air, water and industrial-waste pollution have significantly damaged human health such as skin, eyes, cardiovascular and central nervous systems []. The poisonous materials contain some anions, some cations and some hazardous explosive substances. Nitrobenzene (NB) has looked as a possible carcinogenic or mutagenic agent, which is widely used in industrial manufacturing and military operations []. As is well known, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion may ultimately induce certain cancer because of various physiological disorders []. Over-use of HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion in many industrial and environmental processes which have caused serious environmental problems []. Above all, selective and sensitive detection of pollution and explosive substances causes the wide attention of scientific research workers. Up to now, there have many methods been used for selective and sensitive detection of pollutant and explosive substances. Fluorescence quenching based detection method using luminescent metal-organic complex is more timesaving, cheaper and more convenient than others [].</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Three novel luminescent d10-based Coordination Polymers (CPs) have been synthesized and structurally characterized.

Complex 1 can be sensing recyclable of NB, Fe3+ ion and HSO4 - anion.

Complex 1 was conducted from multi-arm zwitterion ligand.

Nowadays, with the development of modern industry, environmental pollution has become a worldwide problem. Air, water and industrial-waste pollution have significantly damaged human health such as skin, eyes, cardiovascular and central nervous systems []. The poisonous materials contain some anions, some cations and some hazardous explosive substances. Nitrobenzene (NB) has looked as a possible carcinogenic or mutagenic agent, which is widely used in industrial manufacturing and military operations []. As is well known, Fe3+ ion may ultimately induce certain cancer because of various physiological disorders []. Over-use of HSO4 - anion in many industrial and environmental processes which have caused serious environmental problems []. Above all, selective and sensitive detection of pollution and explosive substances causes the wide attention of scientific research workers. Up to now, there have many methods been used for selective and sensitive detection of pollutant and explosive substances. Fluorescence quenching based detection method using luminescent metal-organic complex is more timesaving, cheaper and more convenient than others [].

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">In this present work, we herein use two different multi-arm zwitterionic ligands which are 1,1′,1″‑(2,4,6‑trimethylbenzene‑1,3,5‑triyl)tris(methylene)tris‑(4‑carboxypyridinium)tribromide (L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>) and 1,2,4,5‑tetrakis‑(4‑carboxylatopyridinium‑1‑methylene)benzene (L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) with d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> transition metal ions to construct three new coordination polymers. There is an electropositive aromatic ring in the zwitterionic ligands which contains the structure of nicotinic acid. The electropositive part can neutralize the electronegativity of protonation of carboxyl and increase other anions' competitive coordination ability. Because of the zwitterionic complexes possessing various structures and potential applications in molecular luminescence it has attracted considerable attention for decades []. Until now, some zwitterionic coordination polymers (CPs) have been reported by the groups of Xiao-Zeng You, En-Qing Gao, Yu-Peng Tian and so on []. And our lab developed a double-arm zwitterion ligand Cd-MOF dual-functional luminescent sensing material []. Because of zwitterionic ligands' very large sterichindrance, the most studied ligands often have one or two nicotinic acids, and less research three or more nicotinic acids. Numerous investigations luminescent CPs-based sensors for detecting the poisonous materials have been reported, but most of them reported so far exhibit mainly mono-function. Only a few CPs have been reported in multi-functional luminescent detection []. To the best of our knowledge, most of high selective luminescent CPs sensors for detecting were conducted from d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> transition metal ions and conjugated ligands. The d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal ions are uneasy to cause fluorescence quenching due to their full electron in orbit structure []. In this work, we report three d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> complexes, based on two different multi-arm zwitterionic ligands and their photoluminescent properties were investigated. Thereinto, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as a multi-functional luminescent sensor can exhibit selective sensing for NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions in the ethanol solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this present work, we herein use two different multi-arm zwitterionic ligands which are 1,1',1"-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl)tris(methylene)tris-(4-carboxypyridinium)tribromide (L1) and 1,2,4,5-tetrakis-(4-carboxylatopyridinium-1-methylene)benzene (L2) with d10 transition metal ions to construct three new coordination polymers. There is an electropositive aromatic ring in the zwitterionic ligands which contains the structure of nicotinic acid. The electropositive part can neutralize the electronegativity of protonation of carboxyl and increase other anions' competitive coordination ability. Because of the zwitterionic complexes possessing various structures and potential applications in molecular luminescence it has attracted considerable attention for decades []. Until now, some zwitterionic coordination polymers (CPs) have been reported by the groups of Xiao-Zeng You, En-Qing Gao, Yu-Peng Tian and so on []. And our lab developed a double-arm zwitterion ligand Cd-MOF dual-functional luminescent sensing material []. Because of zwitterionic ligands' very large sterichindrance, the most studied ligands often have one or two nicotinic acids, and less research three or more nicotinic acids. Numerous investigations luminescent CPs-based sensors for detecting the poisonous materials have been reported, but most of them reported so far exhibit mainly mono-function. Only a few CPs have been reported in multi-functional luminescent detection []. To the best of our knowledge, most of high selective luminescent CPs sensors for detecting were conducted from d10 transition metal ions and conjugated ligands. The d10 metal ions are uneasy to cause fluorescence quenching due to their full electron in orbit structure []. In this work, we report three d10 complexes, based on two different multi-arm zwitterionic ligands and their photoluminescent properties were investigated. Thereinto, complex 1 as a multi-functional luminescent sensor can exhibit selective sensing for NB, Fe3+ ions and HSO4 - anions in the ethanol solution.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The detailed procedure of synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were given in the ESI. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is charactered by Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. And the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> belongs to the monoclinic system <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, there are one Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, one L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>, half a BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, three coordinated water molecules, one free Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, one free ethylalcohol and three free water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The central metal atom coordinates a deformed octahedral configuration with six atoms, in which including two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1—O4 = 2.303 Å, Cd1—O9 = 2.354 Å) donors from L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>, one carboxylate oxygen donors (Cd1—O1 = 2.265 Å) from BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and three oxygen atoms (average Cd1—O = 2.307 Å) donors from three coordinated water molecules. Each L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> is connected to two adjacent Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions to form a one-dimensional <ce:italic>zig</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>zag</ce:italic> linear chain. And each BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> is connected to the chain through adjacent Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions to generate a one-dimensional trapezoidal double stranded structure, which can be extended indefinitely. From the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> direction, it looks like a deformed <ce:italic>s</ce:italic>-shaped structure. In the direction of <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, there are small pores (20.768 × 4.531 Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) on the microscopic surface.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The detailed procedure of synthesis of complex 1, 2 and 3 were given in the ESI. The crystal structure of 1 is charactered by Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. And the complex 1 belongs to the monoclinic system C2/c space group. As shown in  , there are one Cd2+ ion, one L1, half a BDC2-, three coordinated water molecules, one free Br- anion, one free ethylalcohol and three free water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The central metal atom coordinates a deformed octahedral configuration with six atoms, in which including two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1-O4=2.303Å, Cd1-O9=2.354Å) donors from L1, one carboxylate oxygen donors (Cd1-O1=2.265Å) from BDC2- and three oxygen atoms (average Cd1-O=2.307Å) donors from three coordinated water molecules. Each L1 is connected to two adjacent Cd2+ ions to form a one-dimensional zig-zag linear chain. And each BDC2- is connected to the chain through adjacent Cd2+ ions to generate a one-dimensional trapezoidal double stranded structure, which can be extended indefinitely. From the b direction, it looks like a deformed s-shaped structure. In the direction of c, there are small pores (20.768×4.531Å2) on the microscopic surface.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Colorless crystals of [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were obtained by room temperature volatile method. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was charactered by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Fig. S5, we can conclude that the crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is the similar as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Here, we describe complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as a sample. The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> belongs to triclinic crystal system <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī space group. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, there are one Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, one L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, six coordinated water molecules, two free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, and half a free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All of four isonicotinic acids are tilted to one side, and the configuration of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> is changed from plane to boat. Two free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions balance the charge of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions. There are hydrogen bonds connecting different layers [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, so that the zero-dimensional complex can form three-dimensional supramolecular structure. There are three types of hydrogen bond in this complex. Firstly, the crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> which the central metal atoms coordinated by six oxygen atoms from water molecules appears as mono-nuclear units, weakly bonded to one another through hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.7475–2.8663 Å) with oxygen atoms from carboxyl of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming a one-dimensional chain. Secondly, each chain is interconnected through hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.714–2.9250 Å) with oxygen atoms from free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming the supramolecular polymers. Thirdly, there also have been hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.7217–2.7962 Å) among binding water molecules interconnection. Details of all hydrogen bonding interactions are given in Table S5. And structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is the similar to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> but the central metal Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Colorless crystals of [Zn(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (2) and [Cd(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (3) were obtained by room temperature volatile method. The crystal structure of 2 was charactered by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Fig. S5, we can conclude that the crystal structure of 3 is the similar as 2. Here, we describe complex 2 as a sample. The complex 2 belongs to triclinic crystal system Pī space group. As shown in  , there are one Zn2+ ion, one L2, six coordinated water molecules, two free NO3 - anions, and half a free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All of four isonicotinic acids are tilted to one side, and the configuration of L2 is changed from plane to boat. Two free NO3 - anions balance the charge of Zn2+ ions. There are hydrogen bonds connecting different layers [Zn(H2O)6]2+, so that the zero-dimensional complex can form three-dimensional supramolecular structure. There are three types of hydrogen bond in this complex. Firstly, the crystal structure of 2 which the central metal atoms coordinated by six oxygen atoms from water molecules appears as mono-nuclear units, weakly bonded to one another through hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.7475-2.8663Å) with oxygen atoms from carboxyl of L2 acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming a one-dimensional chain. Secondly, each chain is interconnected through hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.714-2.9250Å) with oxygen atoms from free NO3 - acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming the supramolecular polymers. Thirdly, there also have been hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.7217-2.7962Å) among binding water molecules interconnection. Details of all hydrogen bonding interactions are given in Table S5. And structure of 3 is the similar to 2 but the central metal Cd2+.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The TG curve for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows in Fig. S3, the thermal stability of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was conducted at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 25 to 850 °C in a flowing atmosphere of nitrogen. The first stage of weight loss from 50 to 185 °C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 13.78%, calcd. 16.14%). Loss steps from 230 to 700 °C are attributed to removal of L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 67.17%, calcd. 66.88%). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are in the same experiment condition. The first stage of weight loss from 32 to 140 °C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 12.83%, calcd. 17.37%). Loss steps from 230 to 800 °C are attributed to removal of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 57.63%, calcd. 66.66%). The reason why the experimental value is less than the calculated value is that the residue contains ZnO (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), CdO (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and undecomposed carbon-containing compound. As shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S5, we could conclude that the samples are good phase purity through the PXRD patterns for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The TG curve for 1 shows in Fig. S3, the thermal stability of complex 1 was conducted at a heating rate of 10°C/min from 25 to 850°C in a flowing atmosphere of nitrogen. The first stage of weight loss from 50 to 185°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 13.78%, calcd. 16.14%). Loss steps from 230 to 700°C are attributed to removal of L1 and BDC2-, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 67.17%, calcd. 66.88%). The complex 2 and 3 are in the same experiment condition. The first stage of weight loss from 32 to 140°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 12.83%, calcd. 17.37%). Loss steps from 230 to 800°C are attributed to removal of L2, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 57.63%, calcd. 66.66%). The reason why the experimental value is less than the calculated value is that the residue contains ZnO (2), CdO (3) and undecomposed carbon-containing compound. As shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S5, we could conclude that the samples are good phase purity through the PXRD patterns for complex 1, 2 and 3.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Consulting the previous studies have shown that d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>-CPs exhibit luminescent properties []. The emission spectrum of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> exhibits two broad emission bands at 425 nm and 475 nm, besides, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC exhibits a broad emission band at 385 nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((a)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar to the free L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed two emission peaks at 365 nm and 470 nm. Compared with the free ligand, the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showed a weaker emission band blue-shifted to different extent, which probably originates from the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> motivated us to investigate its potential application in the detection of small molecules, ions and anions. The luminescence spectra of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and the sample of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in solid state were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 300 nm, respectively. The emission spectrum of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> exhibits two broad emission bands at 425 nm and 475 nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((b)). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> displayed two emission peaks at 420 nm and 460 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Consulting the previous studies have shown that d10-CPs exhibit luminescent properties []. The emission spectrum of the free L1 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, besides, H2BDC exhibits a broad emission band at 385nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((a)). Similar to the free L1 and H2BDC, the complex 1 displayed two emission peaks at 365nm and 470nm. Compared with the free ligand, the 1 showed a weaker emission band blue-shifted to different extent, which probably originates from the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescence of 1 motivated us to investigate its potential application in the detection of small molecules, ions and anions. The luminescence spectra of the free L2 and the sample of complex 2 and 3 in solid state were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 300nm, respectively. The emission spectrum of the free L2 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((b)). The complex 2 and 3 displayed two emission peaks at 420nm and 460nm.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The luminescence of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> inspires us to investigate its potential application for sensing different types of small molecules. The complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> samples were dispersed in common small organic molecule solvents which were DMF, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, DMSO, DMA, Pyridine, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN, Ethylalcohol, Acetone, Ethylacetate, and NB. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1 mM []. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, different small organic molecule solvents can result in different effect on the fluorescence intensity of the dispersed solution of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of organic solvent included samples largely depends on different solvents, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order EtOH > MeOH > Py > Acetone > DCM > DMSO > EtOAc > Water > DMA > DMF > MeCN > NB. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays the strongest emission in Ethylalcohol while shows nearly complete quenching effect in the NB suspension. This result indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be used as a fluorescent sensor for the selective detection of NB. For better understanding of the sensing ability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards NB, a series of suspensions of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the gradual addition of analyte in the ethylalcohol system are prepared to record the emissive response []. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing NB concentration. When the concentration of NB in the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of ethanol suspension reaches 75.0 μM, the fluorescence is almost completely quenched with a quench percentage of 87.4%. The fluorescence quenching of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were calculated by using the Stern-Volmer equation (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> = 1 + <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf>[M]), where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> represents the initial intensity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the absence of analyte, <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [M], and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> is the quenching constant []. According to the quenching experimental data, the dose−response graph fitted the relationship <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> = 0.4876e^([NB]/27.81)-0.6842 (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.9976) in (c). Importantly, the S–V curves deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that more than one quenching mechanism appear in the process, which can be attributed to the presence of simultaneous dynamic and static quenching []. We also researched the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> for sensing these chemicals. They only can sense for NB, and the fluorescence quenching of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is less than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S6). They cannot good enough to sense for these anions and ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The luminescence of complex 1 inspires us to investigate its potential application for sensing different types of small molecules. The complex 1 samples were dispersed in common small organic molecule solvents which were DMF, H2O, DMSO, DMA, Pyridine, CH2Cl2, CH3CN, Ethylalcohol, Acetone, Ethylacetate, and NB. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1mM []. As depicted in  , different small organic molecule solvents can result in different effect on the fluorescence intensity of the dispersed solution of 1. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of organic solvent included samples largely depends on different solvents, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order EtOH>MeOH>Py>Acetone>DCM>DMSO>EtOAc>Water>DMA>DMF>MeCN>NB. Compound 1 displays the strongest emission in Ethylalcohol while shows nearly complete quenching effect in the NB suspension. This result indicates that compound 1 can be used as a fluorescent sensor for the selective detection of NB. For better understanding of the sensing ability of 1 towards NB, a series of suspensions of complex 1 with the gradual addition of analyte in the ethylalcohol system are prepared to record the emissive response []. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing NB concentration. When the concentration of NB in the complex 1 of ethanol suspension reaches 75.0μM, the fluorescence is almost completely quenched with a quench percentage of 87.4%. The fluorescence quenching of complex 1 were calculated by using the Stern-Volmer equation (I 0/I=1+K SV[M]), where I 0 represents the initial intensity of 1 in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [M], and K SV is the quenching constant []. According to the quenching experimental data, the dose-response graph fitted the relationship I 0/I=0.4876e^([NB]/27.81)-0.6842 (R2=0.9976) in (c). Importantly, the S-V curves deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that more than one quenching mechanism appear in the process, which can be attributed to the presence of simultaneous dynamic and static quenching []. We also researched the complex 2 and 3 for sensing these chemicals. They only can sense for NB, and the fluorescence quenching of 2 and 3 is less than 1 (Fig. S6). They cannot good enough to sense for these anions and ions.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">As shown in (d)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol with the low concentrations of NB is 0.9992, suggesting that the quenching effect of NB on the fluorescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> fits well the Stern–Volmer model. From the linear fitting of the S–V plot, the calculated <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> values was found to be 3.8370 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at low concentrations of NB. The slope of this graph indicates a very low detection limit of 0.39 ppb for NB (3<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>/slope, where <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> is the standard deviation (5.02 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−7</ce:sup>) calculated by measuring the luminescent intensity of a blank solution 10 times) []. Fig. S7 shows that the PXRD pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol with NB and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol-immersed suggests that the retention of the basic structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after the use of selective sensing. Meanwhile, the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> particles could be regenerated and reused for another sample through centrifuging of the dispersed crystals in ethanol after sensing and washing several times.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: As shown in (d), the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of 1-ethanol with the low concentrations of NB is 0.9992, suggesting that the quenching effect of NB on the fluorescence of 1 fits well the Stern-Volmer model. From the linear fitting of the S-V plot, the calculated K SV values was found to be 3.8370×104M-1 at low concentrations of NB. The slope of this graph indicates a very low detection limit of 0.39ppb for NB (3δ/slope, where δ is the standard deviation (5.02×10-7) calculated by measuring the luminescent intensity of a blank solution 10 times) []. Fig. S7 shows that the PXRD pattern of 1, 1-ethanol with NB and 1-ethanol-immersed suggests that the retention of the basic structure of 1 after the use of selective sensing. Meanwhile, the 1 particles could be regenerated and reused for another sample through centrifuging of the dispersed crystals in ethanol after sensing and washing several times.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The excellent luminescent property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also inspires us to investigate its potential application in detection of common metal ions and anions. The common metal ions-response luminescent behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated by suspending samples into ethanol solvents. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1 mM. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of common metal ions-ethanol luminescent behavior included samples largely depends on different common metal ions, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> > Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>. Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion only can bring essentially complete quenching to the luminescence intensity. When the concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion in the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of ethanol suspension reaches 55 μM, the fluorescence is quenched with a quench percentage of 67.1%. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> concentration. As illustrated in (c), a good linear correlation was observed for the plot of <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> = 1 + <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> [Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>] in the range from 5 μM to 55 μM. According to the equation, the <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> calculated by linear regression of the plots was 3.69 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.9984), manifesting the selectivity and sensitivity for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. Additionally, recycles of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion detecting experiments were performed and complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can recover its luminescence after filtration and washing by ethanol for several times.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The excellent luminescent property of 1 also inspires us to investigate its potential application in detection of common metal ions and anions. The common metal ions-response luminescent behavior of 1 was investigated by suspending samples into ethanol solvents. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1mM. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of common metal ions-ethanol luminescent behavior included samples largely depends on different common metal ions, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order Zn2+>Cd2+>Pb2+>Al3+>Mg2+>Fe3+. Fe3+ ion only can bring essentially complete quenching to the luminescence intensity. When the concentration of Fe3+ ion in the complex 1 of ethanol suspension reaches 55μM, the fluorescence is quenched with a quench percentage of 67.1%. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing Fe3+ concentration. As illustrated in (c), a good linear correlation was observed for the plot of I 0/I=1+K SV [Fe3+] in the range from 5μM to 55μM. According to the equation, the K SV calculated by linear regression of the plots was 3.69×104M-1 (R2=0.9984), manifesting the selectivity and sensitivity for Fe3+ ion. Additionally, recycles of Fe3+ ion detecting experiments were performed and complex 1 can recover its luminescence after filtration and washing by ethanol for several times.

elements.clean_text: It can be clearly seen from the spectra shown in (a), the fluorescence of 1-ethanol adding HSO4 - exhibited obvious fluorescence change, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order SO3 2 ->S2O5 2 ->S2O3 2 ->SO4 2 ->HSO4 -. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing HSO4 - concentration. In the light of the quenching experimental data, the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of 1-ethanol adding HSO4 - is 0.9958 in (c), suggesting that the quenching effect of HSO4 -on the fluorescence of 1-ethanol fits well the Stern-Volmer model. The K SV is 4.86×103M-1 of HSO4 -, which indicates some selective sensing of HSO4 - anion. In the same way, recycles of HSO4 - anion detecting experiments were performed and complex 1 can recover its luminescence after filtration and washing by ethanol for several times (Fig. S7).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The possible reason for the luminescence quenching may be ascribed to the photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism, which is the similar with that reported in previous work []. And some researchers reported that the S–V curves also deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that dynamic quenching and static quenching in the process []. It is reported that this static quenching may be due to the electrostatic interactions between the pyridine cations of zwitterionic ligands and hydroxyl groups of NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, while the dynamic one may be due to the collisional encounters between the fluorene moieties and samples []. To research in depth the mechanism of luminescence quenching, the UV–vis absorption spectra of the analytes in the aqueous phase were recorded. As shown in Fig. S9, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion has three strong absorption in the relatively broad (wavelength ranges of 215–245 nm, 245–300 nm and 300–400 nm) in the UV–Vis absorption spectrum, and NB has a strong absorption in the relatively broad (wavelength range of 215–400 nm) in the UV–Vis absorption spectrum which cover the values of the excitation peaks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (365 nm), while HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion has a weak absorption in (wavelength range of 275–375 nm) and a strong absorption at 220 nm. In other words, the Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and NB can absorb the excitation light of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, hence decreasing and even quenching the luminescence intensities. And HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion can weakly absorb the excitation light of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, accordingly decreasing the luminescence intensities slightly []. As shown in Fig. S10 and (a), HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion exhibited obvious fluorescence change than SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, which can simply be due to difference in pH. As can be seen from (a), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the decreasing in pH.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The possible reason for the luminescence quenching may be ascribed to the photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism, which is the similar with that reported in previous work []. And some researchers reported that the S-V curves also deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that dynamic quenching and static quenching in the process []. It is reported that this static quenching may be due to the electrostatic interactions between the pyridine cations of zwitterionic ligands and hydroxyl groups of NB, Fe3+ ion and HSO4 - anion, while the dynamic one may be due to the collisional encounters between the fluorene moieties and samples []. To research in depth the mechanism of luminescence quenching, the UV-vis absorption spectra of the analytes in the aqueous phase were recorded. As shown in Fig. S9, Fe3+ ion has three strong absorption in the relatively broad (wavelength ranges of 215-245nm, 245-300nm and 300-400nm) in the UV-Vis absorption spectrum, and NB has a strong absorption in the relatively broad (wavelength range of 215-400nm) in the UV-Vis absorption spectrum which cover the values of the excitation peaks of 1 (365nm), while HSO4 - anion has a weak absorption in (wavelength range of 275-375nm) and a strong absorption at 220nm. In other words, the Fe3+ ion and NB can absorb the excitation light of 1, hence decreasing and even quenching the luminescence intensities. And HSO4 - anion can weakly absorb the excitation light of 1, accordingly decreasing the luminescence intensities slightly []. As shown in Fig. S10 and (a), HSO4 - anion exhibited obvious fluorescence change than SO4 2- anion, which can simply be due to difference in pH. As can be seen from (a), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the decreasing in pH.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In summary, there are three new complexes which contain a zero-dimensional Cd-CPs (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), two zero-dimensional Zn-CPs (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and Cd-CPs (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) have been successfully synthesized by the solvothermal method and room temperature volatile method. These effects through fluorescence quenching based detection method indicated that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be utilized as chemosensor to selectively detect NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, which could be regenerated and reused. But the fluorescence quenching effects of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are not good enough to detect NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion. The results suggest that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be applied as a Cd-CPs derived from multi-arm zwitterionic ligands that might be a multi-functional potential luminescent probe for the detection of NB, Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion and HSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>anion in ethanol solution. Further studies are underway in our lab.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, there are three new complexes which contain a zero-dimensional Cd-CPs (1), two zero-dimensional Zn-CPs (2) and Cd-CPs (3) have been successfully synthesized by the solvothermal method and room temperature volatile method. These effects through fluorescence quenching based detection method indicated that complex 1 can be utilized as chemosensor to selectively detect NB, Fe3+ ions and HSO4 - anions, which could be regenerated and reused. But the fluorescence quenching effects of complex 2 and 3 are not good enough to detect NB, Fe3+ ion and HSO4 - anion. The results suggest that 1 can be applied as a Cd-CPs derived from multi-arm zwitterionic ligands that might be a multi-functional potential luminescent probe for the detection of NB, Fe3+ ion and HSO4 -anion in ethanol solution. Further studies are underway in our lab.

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The detailed procedure of synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were given in the ESI. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is charactered by Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. And the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> belongs to the monoclinic system <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> space group. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, there are one Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, one L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>, half a BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, three coordinated water molecules, one free Br<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anion, one free ethylalcohol and three free water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The central metal atom coordinates a deformed octahedral configuration with six atoms, in which including two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1—O4 = 2.303 Å, Cd1—O9 = 2.354 Å) donors from L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>, one carboxylate oxygen donors (Cd1—O1 = 2.265 Å) from BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and three oxygen atoms (average Cd1—O = 2.307 Å) donors from three coordinated water molecules. Each L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> is connected to two adjacent Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions to form a one-dimensional <ce:italic>zig</ce:italic>-<ce:italic>zag</ce:italic> linear chain. And each BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> is connected to the chain through adjacent Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions to generate a one-dimensional trapezoidal double stranded structure, which can be extended indefinitely. From the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> direction, it looks like a deformed <ce:italic>s</ce:italic>-shaped structure. In the direction of <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>, there are small pores (20.768 × 4.531 Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) on the microscopic surface.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Colorless crystals of [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [Cd(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·2NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were obtained by room temperature volatile method. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was charactered by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Fig. S5, we can conclude that the crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is the similar as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Here, we describe complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as a sample. The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> belongs to triclinic crystal system <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>ī space group. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>, there are one Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion, one L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, six coordinated water molecules, two free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions, and half a free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All of four isonicotinic acids are tilted to one side, and the configuration of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> is changed from plane to boat. Two free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions balance the charge of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions. There are hydrogen bonds connecting different layers [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, so that the zero-dimensional complex can form three-dimensional supramolecular structure. There are three types of hydrogen bond in this complex. Firstly, the crystal structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> which the central metal atoms coordinated by six oxygen atoms from water molecules appears as mono-nuclear units, weakly bonded to one another through hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.7475–2.8663 Å) with oxygen atoms from carboxyl of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming a one-dimensional chain. Secondly, each chain is interconnected through hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.714–2.9250 Å) with oxygen atoms from free NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming the supramolecular polymers. Thirdly, there also have been hydrogen bonds (O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H⋯O = 2.7217–2.7962 Å) among binding water molecules interconnection. Details of all hydrogen bonding interactions are given in Table S5. And structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is the similar to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> but the central metal Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The TG curve for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows in Fig. S3, the thermal stability of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was conducted at a heating rate of 10 °C/min from 25 to 850 °C in a flowing atmosphere of nitrogen. The first stage of weight loss from 50 to 185 °C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 13.78%, calcd. 16.14%). Loss steps from 230 to 700 °C are attributed to removal of L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and BDC<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 67.17%, calcd. 66.88%). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are in the same experiment condition. The first stage of weight loss from 32 to 140 °C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 12.83%, calcd. 17.37%). Loss steps from 230 to 800 °C are attributed to removal of L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 57.63%, calcd. 66.66%). The reason why the experimental value is less than the calculated value is that the residue contains ZnO (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), CdO (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and undecomposed carbon-containing compound. As shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S5, we could conclude that the samples are good phase purity through the PXRD patterns for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Consulting the previous studies have shown that d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>-CPs exhibit luminescent properties []. The emission spectrum of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> exhibits two broad emission bands at 425 nm and 475 nm, besides, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC exhibits a broad emission band at 385 nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((a)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar to the free L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC, the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed two emission peaks at 365 nm and 470 nm. Compared with the free ligand, the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> showed a weaker emission band blue-shifted to different extent, which probably originates from the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> motivated us to investigate its potential application in the detection of small molecules, ions and anions. The luminescence spectra of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and the sample of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in solid state were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 300 nm, respectively. The emission spectrum of the free L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> exhibits two broad emission bands at 425 nm and 475 nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((b)). The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> displayed two emission peaks at 420 nm and 460 nm.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The luminescence of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> inspires us to investigate its potential application for sensing different types of small molecules. The complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> samples were dispersed in common small organic molecule solvents which were DMF, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, DMSO, DMA, Pyridine, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN, Ethylalcohol, Acetone, Ethylacetate, and NB. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1 mM []. As depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>, different small organic molecule solvents can result in different effect on the fluorescence intensity of the dispersed solution of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of organic solvent included samples largely depends on different solvents, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order EtOH > MeOH > Py > Acetone > DCM > DMSO > EtOAc > Water > DMA > DMF > MeCN > NB. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays the strongest emission in Ethylalcohol while shows nearly complete quenching effect in the NB suspension. This result indicates that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be used as a fluorescent sensor for the selective detection of NB. For better understanding of the sensing ability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> towards NB, a series of suspensions of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the gradual addition of analyte in the ethylalcohol system are prepared to record the emissive response []. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing NB concentration. When the concentration of NB in the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of ethanol suspension reaches 75.0 μM, the fluorescence is almost completely quenched with a quench percentage of 87.4%. The fluorescence quenching of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were calculated by using the Stern-Volmer equation (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> = 1 + <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf>[M]), where <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> represents the initial intensity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in the absence of analyte, <ce:italic>I</ce:italic> is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [M], and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> is the quenching constant []. According to the quenching experimental data, the dose−response graph fitted the relationship <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> = 0.4876e^([NB]/27.81)-0.6842 (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.9976) in (c). Importantly, the S–V curves deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that more than one quenching mechanism appear in the process, which can be attributed to the presence of simultaneous dynamic and static quenching []. We also researched the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> for sensing these chemicals. They only can sense for NB, and the fluorescence quenching of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is less than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Fig. S6). They cannot good enough to sense for these anions and ions.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">As shown in (d)<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol with the low concentrations of NB is 0.9992, suggesting that the quenching effect of NB on the fluorescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> fits well the Stern–Volmer model. From the linear fitting of the S–V plot, the calculated <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> values was found to be 3.8370 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at low concentrations of NB. The slope of this graph indicates a very low detection limit of 0.39 ppb for NB (3<ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>/slope, where <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> is the standard deviation (5.02 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−7</ce:sup>) calculated by measuring the luminescent intensity of a blank solution 10 times) []. Fig. S7 shows that the PXRD pattern of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol with NB and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-ethanol-immersed suggests that the retention of the basic structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> after the use of selective sensing. Meanwhile, the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> particles could be regenerated and reused for another sample through centrifuging of the dispersed crystals in ethanol after sensing and washing several times.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
The detailed procedure of synthesis of complex 1, 2 and 3 were given in the ESI. The crystal structure of 1 is charactered by Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. And the complex 1 belongs to the monoclinic system C2/c space group. As shown in  , there are one Cd2+ ion, one L1, half a BDC2-, three coordinated water molecules, one free Br- anion, one free ethylalcohol and three free water molecules in the asymmetric unit. The central metal atom coordinates a deformed octahedral configuration with six atoms, in which including two different carboxylate oxygen atoms (Cd1-O4=2.303Å, Cd1-O9=2.354Å) donors from L1, one carboxylate oxygen donors (Cd1-O1=2.265Å) from BDC2- and three oxygen atoms (average Cd1-O=2.307Å) donors from three coordinated water molecules. Each L1 is connected to two adjacent Cd2+ ions to form a one-dimensional zig-zag linear chain. And each BDC2- is connected to the chain through adjacent Cd2+ ions to generate a one-dimensional trapezoidal double stranded structure, which can be extended indefinitely. From the b direction, it looks like a deformed s-shaped structure. In the direction of c, there are small pores (20.768×4.531Å2) on the microscopic surface.

Colorless crystals of [Zn(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (2) and [Cd(H2O)6]⋅L2⋅2NO3 -⋅0.5H2O (3) were obtained by room temperature volatile method. The crystal structure of 2 was charactered by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. As shown in Fig. S5, we can conclude that the crystal structure of 3 is the similar as 2. Here, we describe complex 2 as a sample. The complex 2 belongs to triclinic crystal system Pī space group. As shown in  , there are one Zn2+ ion, one L2, six coordinated water molecules, two free NO3 - anions, and half a free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All of four isonicotinic acids are tilted to one side, and the configuration of L2 is changed from plane to boat. Two free NO3 - anions balance the charge of Zn2+ ions. There are hydrogen bonds connecting different layers [Zn(H2O)6]2+, so that the zero-dimensional complex can form three-dimensional supramolecular structure. There are three types of hydrogen bond in this complex. Firstly, the crystal structure of 2 which the central metal atoms coordinated by six oxygen atoms from water molecules appears as mono-nuclear units, weakly bonded to one another through hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.7475-2.8663Å) with oxygen atoms from carboxyl of L2 acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming a one-dimensional chain. Secondly, each chain is interconnected through hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.714-2.9250Å) with oxygen atoms from free NO3 - acceptor and hydrogen atoms from binding water donor forming the supramolecular polymers. Thirdly, there also have been hydrogen bonds (OH⋯O=2.7217-2.7962Å) among binding water molecules interconnection. Details of all hydrogen bonding interactions are given in Table S5. And structure of 3 is the similar to 2 but the central metal Cd2+.

The TG curve for 1 shows in Fig. S3, the thermal stability of complex 1 was conducted at a heating rate of 10°C/min from 25 to 850°C in a flowing atmosphere of nitrogen. The first stage of weight loss from 50 to 185°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 13.78%, calcd. 16.14%). Loss steps from 230 to 700°C are attributed to removal of L1 and BDC2-, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 67.17%, calcd. 66.88%). The complex 2 and 3 are in the same experiment condition. The first stage of weight loss from 32 to 140°C corresponds to release of free water and free ethylalcohol (expt. 12.83%, calcd. 17.37%). Loss steps from 230 to 800°C are attributed to removal of L2, which means collapse of the three-dimensional structure (expt. 57.63%, calcd. 66.66%). The reason why the experimental value is less than the calculated value is that the residue contains ZnO (2), CdO (3) and undecomposed carbon-containing compound. As shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. S5, we could conclude that the samples are good phase purity through the PXRD patterns for complex 1, 2 and 3.

Consulting the previous studies have shown that d10-CPs exhibit luminescent properties []. The emission spectrum of the free L1 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, besides, H2BDC exhibits a broad emission band at 385nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((a)). Similar to the free L1 and H2BDC, the complex 1 displayed two emission peaks at 365nm and 470nm. Compared with the free ligand, the 1 showed a weaker emission band blue-shifted to different extent, which probably originates from the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The luminescence of 1 motivated us to investigate its potential application in the detection of small molecules, ions and anions. The luminescence spectra of the free L2 and the sample of complex 2 and 3 in solid state were investigated at room temperature under excitation at 300nm, respectively. The emission spectrum of the free L2 exhibits two broad emission bands at 425nm and 475nm, which can be attributed to the ligand-centered electronic transition (LCET) ((b)). The complex 2 and 3 displayed two emission peaks at 420nm and 460nm.

The luminescence of complex 1 inspires us to investigate its potential application for sensing different types of small molecules. The complex 1 samples were dispersed in common small organic molecule solvents which were DMF, H2O, DMSO, DMA, Pyridine, CH2Cl2, CH3CN, Ethylalcohol, Acetone, Ethylacetate, and NB. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1mM []. As depicted in  , different small organic molecule solvents can result in different effect on the fluorescence intensity of the dispersed solution of 1. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of organic solvent included samples largely depends on different solvents, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order EtOH>MeOH>Py>Acetone>DCM>DMSO>EtOAc>Water>DMA>DMF>MeCN>NB. Compound 1 displays the strongest emission in Ethylalcohol while shows nearly complete quenching effect in the NB suspension. This result indicates that compound 1 can be used as a fluorescent sensor for the selective detection of NB. For better understanding of the sensing ability of 1 towards NB, a series of suspensions of complex 1 with the gradual addition of analyte in the ethylalcohol system are prepared to record the emissive response []. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing NB concentration. When the concentration of NB in the complex 1 of ethanol suspension reaches 75.0μM, the fluorescence is almost completely quenched with a quench percentage of 87.4%. The fluorescence quenching of complex 1 were calculated by using the Stern-Volmer equation (I 0/I=1+K SV[M]), where I 0 represents the initial intensity of 1 in the absence of analyte, I is the emission intensity in the presence of analyte with molar concentration [M], and K SV is the quenching constant []. According to the quenching experimental data, the dose-response graph fitted the relationship I 0/I=0.4876e^([NB]/27.81)-0.6842 (R2=0.9976) in (c). Importantly, the S-V curves deviate from the straight line, and this phenomenon suggests that more than one quenching mechanism appear in the process, which can be attributed to the presence of simultaneous dynamic and static quenching []. We also researched the complex 2 and 3 for sensing these chemicals. They only can sense for NB, and the fluorescence quenching of 2 and 3 is less than 1 (Fig. S6). They cannot good enough to sense for these anions and ions.

As shown in (d), the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of 1-ethanol with the low concentrations of NB is 0.9992, suggesting that the quenching effect of NB on the fluorescence of 1 fits well the Stern-Volmer model. From the linear fitting of the S-V plot, the calculated K SV values was found to be 3.8370×104M-1 at low concentrations of NB. The slope of this graph indicates a very low detection limit of 0.39ppb for NB (3δ/slope, where δ is the standard deviation (5.02×10-7) calculated by measuring the luminescent intensity of a blank solution 10 times) []. Fig. S7 shows that the PXRD pattern of 1, 1-ethanol with NB and 1-ethanol-immersed suggests that the retention of the basic structure of 1 after the use of selective sensing. Meanwhile, the 1 particles could be regenerated and reused for another sample through centrifuging of the dispersed crystals in ethanol after sensing and washing several times.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The excellent luminescent property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> also inspires us to investigate its potential application in detection of common metal ions and anions. The common metal ions-response luminescent behavior of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated by suspending samples into ethanol solvents. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1 mM. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of common metal ions-ethanol luminescent behavior included samples largely depends on different common metal ions, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Al<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> > Mg<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> > Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>. Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion only can bring essentially complete quenching to the luminescence intensity. When the concentration of Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion in the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> of ethanol suspension reaches 55 μM, the fluorescence is quenched with a quench percentage of 67.1%. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> concentration. As illustrated in (c), a good linear correlation was observed for the plot of <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">SV</ce:inf> calculated by linear regression of the plots was 3.69 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (R<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> = 0.9984), manifesting the selectivity and sensitivity for Fe<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion. The excellent luminescent property of 1 also inspires us to investigate its potential application in detection of common metal ions and anions. The common metal ions-response luminescent behavior of 1 was investigated by suspending samples into ethanol solvents. All sample concentration in different organic solvents is 1mM. As shown in (a) the luminescence intensity of common metal ions-ethanol luminescent behavior included samples largely depends on different common metal ions, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order Zn2+>Cd2+>Pb2+>Al3+>Mg2+>Fe3+. Fe3+ ion only can bring essentially complete quenching to the luminescence intensity. When the concentration of Fe3+ ion in the complex 1 of ethanol suspension reaches 55μM, the fluorescence is quenched with a quench percentage of 67.1%. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing Fe3+ concentration. As illustrated in (c), a good linear correlation was observed for the plot of I 0/I=1+K SV [Fe3+] in the range from 5μM to 55μM. According to the equation, the K SV calculated by linear regression of the plots was 3.69×104M-1 (R2=0.9984), manifesting the selectivity and sensitivity for Fe3+ ion. Additionally, recycles of Fe3+ ion detecting experiments were performed and complex 1 can recover its luminescence after filtration and washing by ethanol for several times.

It can be clearly seen from the spectra shown in (a), the fluorescence of 1-ethanol adding HSO4 - exhibited obvious fluorescence change, and the maximum luminescent intensity decreases in the order SO3 2 ->S2O5 2 ->S2O3 2 ->SO4 2 ->HSO4 -. Significant quenching was observed in (b), the luminescence intensity decreases clearly with the increasing HSO4 - concentration. In the light of the quenching experimental data, the linear correlation coefficient (R) in the K SV curve of 1-ethanol adding HSO4 - is 0.9958 in (c), suggesting that the quenching effect of HSO4 -on the fluorescence of 1-ethanol fits well the Stern-Volmer model. The K SV is 4.86×103M-1 of HSO4 -, which indicates some selective sensing of HSO4 - anion. In the same way, recycles of HSO4 - anion detecting experiments were performed and complex 1 can recover its luminescence after filtration and washing by ethanol for several times (Fig. S7).
